review.title: Word Affect Intensities
review.abstract: Words often convey affect -- emotions, feelings, and attitudes. Lexicons of word-affect association have applications in automatic emotion analysis and natural language generation. However, existing lexicons indicate only coarse categories of affect association. Here, for the first time, we create an affect intensity lexicon with real-valued scores of association. We use a technique called best-worst scaling that improves annotation consistency and obtains reliable fine-grained scores. The lexicon includes terms common from both general English and terms specific to social media communications. It has close to 6,000 entries for four basic emotions. We will be adding entries for other affect dimensions shortly.

metadata.title: Word Affect Intensities

sections.text: Words often convey emotions - emotions, feelings and attitudes. Encyclopaedias of affect association have applications in automatic emotion analysis and the generation of natural language. However, existing encyclopaedias only indicate broad categories of affect association. Here, for the first time, we are creating an affect intensity encyclopaedia with real association values. We use a technique called best-worst scaling, which improves the consistency of annotations and achieves reliable fine-grained values. The encyclopaedia includes terms from general English as well as terms specific to social media communication. It has nearly 6,000 entries for four basic emotions. We will soon add entries for other effect dimensions.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: In this project, the goal is to create an affect intensity for the eight emotions: anger, joy, sadness, expectation, and surprise. These are the eight emotions that we consider to be the most basic. (Plutchik, 1980; Parrot, 2001; Frijda, 1988) The eight emotions that we perceive as such are all very different. (In this project, the goal is to create an affect intensity for the eight emotions, the fear, the sadness, the trust, the expectation, and the surprise. These are the eight emotions that we consider to be the most basic.) The eight emotions encompass the six emotions that are considered to be the most basic emotions. (Plutchik, 1980) The six emotions that are considered to be the most basic emotions. (Ekman, 1992)

sections.heading: 3 NRC Affect Intensity Lexicon
sections.text: We now describe how we created the NRC Affect Intensity Lexicon.

sections.heading: 3.1 Term Selection
sections.text: We have chosen to comment on commonly used English terms, as well as terms that are common in social media texts, so the resulting lexicon can be widely used. Twitter has a large and diverse user base that includes rich textual content. 6 tweets have a lot of non-standard language such as emoticons, emojis, creatively spelled words (happee), hashtags (# takingastand, # lonely) and linked words (loveumom). Tweets are often used to convey emotions, opinions on products and attitudes about topics. Therefore, the emotion analysis of tweets is particularly compact. As most words do not convey specific emotion to a pronounced extent, the annotation of all words is suboptimal for all emotions. Thus, for each of the eight emotions we have created separate lists of terms that fulfill either one of the two characteristics we list below: 6Twitter is a social networking and microblogging service where users post messages and tweet up to 140 characters are called The Word.

sections.heading: 3.2 Annotating for Affect Intensity with Best–Worst Scaling
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it has never come as far as this year.

sections.heading: 4 Reliability of the Annotations
sections.text: One cannot use the standard interannotator agreement to determine the quality of the BVS annotations, because the disagreement that arises when a tuple has two points close to each other in emotional intensity is a useful signal for BVS. Therefore, if respondents are unable to uniformly identify the word with the highest (or lowest) emotion intensity, the disagreement results in the two words receiving similar values, which is the desired result. Therefore, a different measure of the quality of the annotations must be used. A useful measure of quality is the reproducibility of the end result - if repeated independent manual annotations by several respondents lead to similar intensity values, then one can be sure that the values capture the true emotion intensities. To evaluate this reproducibility, we calculate the average split-half reliability (SHR) over 100 studies. SHR is a commonly used approach to determine the consistency of the two points we are following in our two observations.

sections.heading: 5 Applications
sections.text: Mohammad and Bravo-Marquez (2017) demonstrate their usefulness in automatically determining the intensity of the emotions transmitted by tweets. They also comment on a data set of tweets in terms of the degree (or intensity) of the emotions experienced by the speaker - the Tweet Emotion Intensity Dataset. The lexicon can be used together with the Tweet Emotion Intensity Dataset to investigate the interplay between the tweet Emotional intensity and the intensity of the words that make up the tweet. The lexicon also has applications in the fields of digital humanities and literary analysis, where it can be used to identify high-intensity words. The NRC Affect Intensity Lexicon can also be used as a source of Gold Intensity Scores to evaluate automatic methods of determining word intensity.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We created the NRC Affect Intensity Lexicon, a broad-ranging lexicon that captures the intensity of word effects for eight basic emotions. We used the best-worst-scaling (BWS) technique to obtain fine-grained values (and word rankings) and address issues of the consistency of notes that plague traditional methods of the annotation scale. We show that repeated annotations of terms in the Affect Intensity Lexicon with independent annotations result in association values that are close to the values originally obtained (Spearman Rank correlations of 0.92; Pearson correlation: 0.91). The fine-grained evaluation achieved with BWS and the high correlations in repetition compositions suggest that BWS is both discriminatory (helps to detect slight differences in affect intensity) and highly reliable (delivers stable results). The lexicon has applications in both the automated composition of words and the constituting effect of words.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: Many thanks to Svetlana Kirichenko and Tara Small for helpful talks.

Best-Worst Scaling (BWS) was developed by Louviere (1991), building on some groundbreaking research in the 1960s in mathematical psychology and psychophysics by Anthony A.

Within the NLP community, BWS has thus far been used for creating datasets for relational similarity (Jurgens et al., 2012), word-sense disambiguation (Jurgens, 2013), and word–sentiment intensity (Kiritchenko and Mohammad, 2016).

For each emotion, we included all terms in the Hashtag Emotion Corpus (Mohammad, 2012) that had a PMI > 1.
We used the script provided by Kiritchenko and Mohammad (2016) to obtain the BWS annotations.

We used the script provided by Kiritchenko and Mohammad (2016) to obtain the BWS annotations.8 Kiritchenko and Mohammad (2016) showed that using just three annotations per 4-tuple produces highly reliable results.

The BWS responses were translated into scores by a simple calculation (Orme, 2009; Flynn and Marley, 2014): For each item, the score is the proportion of times the item was chosen as having the most intensity minus the proportion of times the item was chosen as having the least intensity.

metadata.abstractText: Words often convey affect—emotions, feelings, and attitudes. Lexicons of word– affect association have applications in automatic emotion analysis and natural language generation. However, existing lexicons indicate only coarse categories of affect association. Here, for the first time, we create an affect intensity lexicon with real-valued scores of association. We use a technique called best–worst scaling that improves annotation consistency and obtains reliable fine-grained scores. The lexicon includes terms from general English as well as terms specific to social media communications. It has close to 6,000 entries for four basic emotions. We will be adding entries for other affect dimensions shortly.
